review_title: A good starter, dysfunctional management, poor process management
job_title: in Rapid City, SD
pros: Team atmosphere is great in my department. My direct manager is awesome. Decent pay for the area. Good exposure to a multitude of systems.
cons: Pay is also a con as it is well below national average with no plans to bring it in line. The red tape here is awful, worse than most places. This seems to be a result of poor communication from upper management combined with a weird, secretive aura around every decision being made. Decisions being made are always phrased as being for the benefit of the employee when that's never been the case. Benefits get worse and more restrictive every year while remaining the same price or more expensive in some cases.

job_title: Certified Pharmacy Technician in Rapid City, SD
pros: Very fulfilling many opportunities to move up.
cons: Inpatient pharmacy is a 24/7/365 operating department.

job_title: Occupational Therapy in Rapid City, SD
pros: -great friendly, supportive staff -flexible schedule, -it’s been a great learning experience!
cons: -pay could always be better, however offers lots of benefits; medical, education, etc. really no complaints.

review_title: Long term employees are not compensated. No raise this year.
job_title: HIM in Rapid City, SD
pros: Steady work and nice coworkers
cons: Had a company wide change to hourly salaries a year ago. Essentially, someone coming in now made the same amount of pay as a coworker with over 3 years in the same position. Than told you would not get a cost of living increase on your annual evaluation. So, why even put extra effort if your paying more for health insurance and now your paycheck is less than the year before. No wonder there are so many open positions.

job_title: Health Information Management in Rapid City, SD

job_title: Registered Nurse in Spearfish, SD
pros: The lower level coworkers were supportive of each other.
cons: Management acted as puppet kings and would not advocate for us direct care providers, they are also spread thin across numerous facilities. They demanded we come in on our days off to cover 2 hours at the end of the shifts regularly and guilted us if we said no. They weren't timely or accurate with pay. They ignored voiced concerns for implementing new policies. It's a straight forward dictatorship, if the RNs aren't in the units they want them in, they will make the RNs jobs worse until they are willing to move. Currently, they are trying to direct from clinics to hospitals. This company is a wolf in sheep's clothing. Monument also monopolized healthcare in the area, meaning they keep wages where they want. Keep an eye on HospitalFinances.org.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Rapid City, SD
pros: Work environment is hectic and unfocused. There is no competition around, so this is the place everyone must go to. Never have I seen so many people that have hated there job, and I have worked at more than a few hospitals. A few managers and charge nurses really try hard to keep everyone on the same page, but this is a few out of the whole entity. They depend on travelers and out of town work due to so many turnovers. There is extreme non congruity and will bring in toxic individuals with no where else to work. Other departments have it worse ie. Diagnostic please reconsider before coming here
cons: You will have to write up some bitter employee and the hospital will encourage it. Its do or die here. Everyone here has at least one report on them. If your happy it will make non happy folks upset.

job_title: Nurse Practitioner in Rapid City, SD
pros: The best part of the hospital is the staff. Since there is no competition and the pay is poor, the people who work at this hospital truly work here because they love what they do. The nurses have heart, the techs truly care, and the ancillary staff go above and beyond.
cons: The worst part about this hospital is that it has no competition. The management is not involved with the staff. There is no staff appreciation. You are worked hard and rarely ever thanked. The pay is probably the worst in the US. You truly are a number. The state of South Dakota has the “right to hire, right to fire” clause. You are reminded of that anytime you speak up about any injustices. Your job is on the line, every day. The nursing staff consists of new grads who are there for experience, travel nurses, or those who have been nurses for 20 years and have roots in the area. The management team and up are mostly not from the area and do not understand the rurality of South Dakota.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Rapid City, SD
pros: Good people to work with. Nice facility .
cons: Benefits. Wages and retirement specifically.

job_title: PAs in Rapid City, SD
pros: Great company to work for
cons: There are not any cons.

review_title: There's a reason they're not a highly rated employer
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Rapid City, SD
pros:
- High pay for the area
- Organization has some very talented people working for it
- Lots of different business locations in area to move around in
- In midst of a growth plan which involves image makeover and infrastructure improvements
cons:
- Ineffective management, especially at the higher levels.  Lack of accountability, lot's of finger pointing, passing the buck and excuse making
- Capital management is non-existent, project overruns and high labor costs due to poor financial controls, poor decision making, poor employee relations, and poor employee retention strategies
- Huge turnover issues at mid and lower levels, lot's of favoritism, lack of leadership, too much complaining about how its all the fault of the millennials
- Way too much emphasis on physician recruitment ($$$) not enough on support staff ($)
- Over reliance on travelling nurses at the expense of hours for the permanent staff, no loyalty to the folks that stick around
- Organization tolerates too many problem employees at the expense of the one's doing the right thing, which end up ruining it for everyone.  
- Lack of meaningful communication and too much fluff 

It took a while, but I was finally able to get out and without burning any bridges.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Rapid City, SD
pros: It's a job.  The staff that I work with are the only reason I stay.
cons: Management is horrible!  They constantly are passing the buck or even worse blaming the staff for the problems.  When told about issues nothing gets done about it.  Direct supervisors will choose to ignore a problem or completely deny that they are the problem.  Staff retention is awful and getting worse.  In over 6 years of employment over 16 months of that time has been spent in MANDATORY overtime while managers take 3 week long vacations.  They are not leaders they are bosses.  They do not lead their staff through the tough times they simply stand back and boss them around to do things all the while telling them they aren't doing it good enough.  They do NOT support continuing education even though they say they do.  They will schedule you a night shift the night before mandatory education like ACLS, BLS, etc.  Overall, I would NEVER recommend working for this company.  Staff satisfaction is poor.

job_title: Patient Care Technician in Rapid City, SD
pros: The environment was great. Most of my coworkers were fantastic and made you feel welcome. The good coworkers and the patients are definitely what helped me tolerate the job. It is a great learning environment and you have some opportunities to grow within the organization.
cons: The compensation per hour could have been better. I definitely feel like you are overworked and underpaid. They assign too many patients per caregiver, and want us to spend adequate time with each patient, but it's nearly impossible since you have 8-12 other patients to look after. There isn't enough space in the hospital to accommodate all of the patients. I feel like they jam as many patients as they can into one room to get in as many folks as possible, making the direct care staff suffer. The management's only concern is making as much money as they can off of people, and they don't value their employees enough. One should never get home one night after work and break down because of all the stress, and not ever want to go back to work again, a situation I was in probably 80% of the time.

review_title: Ok place to work . Nice people in general
job_title: Administrative Assistant in Rapid City, SD
pros: Nice people.  Ok benefits. Local job. Good cafeteria and decent food. Good discounts offered through work for the community. Decent hours.
cons:
Low pay a person comes in with 10 years experience you are getting paid what you were 5 years ago. If you are not a nurse you are not valued. No career growth or training in   any other fields but nurses. Not really a career just a job. If you are not a manager it is difficult to do your job as you do not have "access" to the information to do your job. 
No overtime allowed unless you are a nurse. 
The annual reviews only apply to people in direct patient care not other positions.
Make sure that you understand what employees are being asked to do, the work of three with no overtime.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Bangor, ME
pros: During the time that I worked for the department, many exciting and innovative new treatment procedures and patient programs were developed to improve patient care. This was driven from within the department. The department offered state of the art treatment trials that are now  standard of care. The doctors and staff are knowledgeable and very caring. Good place to work.
cons: Upper management was typical for a hospital of that size and in that region. Lots of red tape and very slow decision making.

job_title: Pharmacy Technician in Rapid City, SD
pros:
- It is unlikely that you will get fired.
- Some coworkers actually care about each other and try to have each others back.
cons:
- Very poor benefits package. Cost of health insurance is outrageous when the pay is so low. 
- 10+ hour shifts. Unable to take unpaid lunch break most days due to extreme work load.
- Management is willing to listen to issues, unwilling to make changes. 
- There is no reward for being a good employee, there are no consequences if you are a poor employee.
- No consistency with schedule.
- Very low pay.

review_title: Love the people, Upper Management (ie CEO) needs a clue
job_title: Hospital Coordinator/RN in Rapid City, SD
pros: The floor staff are amazing to work with. These are people who love what they do and want to make a difference in peoples lives. The PPL is good.
cons: The CEO needs to get a clue. Always talking about making cuts, seriously underpaying their nursing staff, since they are the only game in town other than clinic or nursing home.

job_title: Housekeeping in Rapid City, SD
pros: Being that its a hospital they save lives....
cons:
They have no respect for patients or employees. Customers can ask for food or water and the nurse will just blow it off. When my grandpa was in there, they put the blood pressure cuff on so tight that it bruised him and when he told them, they said "it needs to be like that" and when he took off himself, they sedated him..
As a former employee of three months, i will tell you that they dont pay you for all of your hours. I wasnt on their insurance and my pay checks were getting smaller and smaller every pay period and i know i was getting the same amount of hours everytime

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Rapid City, SD
pros: Stable environment and good employees
cons: Extremely weak CEO; who , according to her own words, "learned alot from Brent Phillips". Phillips was fired by the Board at Regional, had a vote of no confidence by the Medical Staff and was previously fired at Mayo in MN and Auoria in Wisconsin. Current CEO, Davidson, was hired by Phillips and is a clone of Phillips. All talk and no action.
